importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the conclusion of the National League Championship Series, culminating in the Dodgers' four-game sweep of the Milwaukee Brewers and setting up their potential World Series matchup.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period surrounding the National League Championship Series, particularly the final game on October 18, 2025, is critical as it determines the Dodgers' path to the World Series and cements Shohei Ohtani’s historic performance.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered an unprecedented performance in Game 4 of the NLCS, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching in the game.
Ohtani became the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first since 1900 to hit a leadoff home run in the playoffs.
Ohtani achieved the first instance in MLB history of hitting three home runs and striking out at least one batter, and striking out 10 in a single game.
This performance occurred after Ohtani pitched in a 13-day stretch, highlighting his physical endurance and dominance.
The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in four games, securing their 26th World Series appearance and fifth NL pennant in the past nine seasons.
Ohtani was named National League Championship Series MVP, with teammates like Freddie Freeman and Clayton Kershaw praising his impact.
The Dodgers have lost only one game in the postseason and have maintained a strong pitching rotation including Ohtani, Blake Snell, Yoshinobu Yamamoto, and Tyler Glasnow.
The article notes that no team has repeated as World Series champions since the Yankees' 1998–2000 run, making the Dodgers' return to the Fall Classic a significant event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, leading the Los Angeles Dodgers to a four-game sweep of the Milwaukee Brewers. Ohtani hit three home runs—427, 469, and 446 feet—pitched six innings in a shutout, struck out 10 batters, and became the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first to hit a leadoff homer in the playoffs. This performance, achieved after pitching in just 13 days, made him the first player in MLB history to hit three home runs and strike out 10 batters in a single game. Ohtani was named NLCS MVP, and the Dodgers’ strong postseason run—losing only one game—sets them up as a formidable World Series opponent. With no team having repeated as World Series champions since the Yankees’ 1998–2000 run, the Dodgers’ return to the Fall Classic is a major moment in baseball history, widely recognized as the 'Shohei Ohtani Game.'
title: Shohei Ohtani’s legendary night leads Los Angeles Dodgers to another World Series, sweeping Milwaukee in 4 games
